images.alt: The Harley Benton PA-100 and Jettenuator are both power attenuators for guitar amplifiers, but they serve different purposes. The PA-100 is a passive attenuator designed to reduce the output volume of a tube amplifier while maintaining its tone. The Jettenuator, on the other hand, is a water sports accessory that attaches to a personal watercraft, using the watercraft's power to propel the user. Essentially, one is for guitar amplification and the other is for water recreation.

#TRIB Trinity Biotech Unveils CGM+: An AI-Native Platform Targeting the $260 Billion AI Wearable Market

https://www.stocktitan.net/news/TRIB/trinity-biotech-unveils-cgm-an-ai-native-platform-targeting-the-260-sgtiep59q74b.html

external.description: Trinity Biotech (Nasdaq: TRIB) has unveiled CGM+, an AI-native continuous glucose monitoring platform targeting the $260 billion AI wearable market. The next-generation wearable biosensor combines glucose monitoring with heart activity, temperature, and physical activity tracking in a single modular device.The CGM+ platform features a minimally invasive electrochemical glucose sensor and proprietary needle-free technology, designed to reduce disposable components and lower care costs. The company anticipates a commercial launch in mid-2026, targeting both clinical and consumer health markets.The global CGM market is projected to grow from $13.28B in 2025 to $28.72B by 2030 (16.68% CAGR). Trinity Biotech plans multiple revenue streams, including device sales, AI analytics subscriptions, and strategic partnerships with healthcare providers, insurers, and digital health platforms.
external.title: Trinity Biotech Unveils CGM+: An AI-Native Platform Targeting the $260 Billion AI Wearable Market

images.alt:
🇺🇸《防止社交平台操控舆论法案》纲要（草案）

注：本人水平有限，本文由ChatGPT生成。

 第一章 总则

第1条【立法目的】
为了保障公民的言论自由、新闻自由与知情权，防止社交平台运营者滥用权力操控舆论、干预选举与政治事务，维护民主制度与国家安全，特制定本法。

第2条【适用范围】
适用于拥有超过100万注册用户或月活跃用户超过50万的社交媒体平台，包括但不限于 X（原Twitter）、Facebook、Instagram、YouTube、TikTok 等。

 第二章 舆论操控行为界定

第3条【禁止性行为】
以下行为被认定为“舆论操控”并被禁止：

1. 平台老板或其代表基于政治立场直接命令删帖、封号；
2. 有组织地压制特定政治人物或政党的内容传播；
3. 通过算法刻意降低特定立场信息的可见度；
4. 将舆论干预作为换取政策支持或商业利益的工具。

第4条【特殊干预说明】
对涉及暴力、恐怖主义、儿童色情、煽动仇恨的内容采取干预措施不构成本法所称“操控舆论”。

 第三章 平台中立机制

第5条【算法透明】
社交平台应公开其内容推荐、审查、屏蔽相关算法逻辑，接受政府或独立委员会年审。

第6条【封禁公示机制】
平台需在48小时内公开说明任何封禁或内容下架的理由，列明涉及内容、标准、审核人、申诉渠道。

第7条【政治中立审查】
建立由各党派推荐的专家组成的“平台中立委员会”，定期审查平台是否存在舆论操控偏向，向公众发布报告。

 第四章 法律责任与制裁

第8条【行政责任】
若平台违反上述规定，由国家通信管理机构对公司处以总营收1%-10%的罚款，视为重大情节的可吊销运营许可。

第9条【刑事责任】
若平台老板个人指使操控舆论影响选举，可处以最高10年监禁。

第10条【申诉权利】
任何被不当删帖或封号的用户，有权向平台中立委员会申诉，并要求平台限期恢复内容。

---

 第五章 附则

第11条【国际合作】
鼓励与其他民主国家建立“数字言论权保障联盟”，共享违规平台黑名单和打击策略。

第12条【施行日期】
本法自公布之日起满90日施行。

---

 📌 附加说明：

 法案鼓励平台中立性制度化，不是全面禁止干预，而是禁止“政治性干预”。
 若涉及总统候选人、议会选举、战争相关言论，需经过多方程序审查后方可下架。
 平台老板不得介入封禁/推荐的具体执行，应由独立伦理团队完成。

---

如果你需要：

 制作一份完整的法案草案（法律条文格式）
 增加适用于中国、欧盟等地区版本
 设计“平台中立委员会”的制度运作方案

建立由各党派推荐的专家组成的“平台中立委员会”，定期审查平台是否存在舆论操控偏向，向公众发布报告。

 第四章 法律责任与制裁

第8条【行政责任】
若平台违反上述规定，由国家通信管理机构对公司处以总营收1%-10%的罚款，视为重大情节的可吊销运营许可。

第9条【刑事责任】
若平台老板个人指使操控舆论影响选举，可处以最高10年监禁。

第10条【申诉权利】
任何被不当删帖或封号的用户，有权向平台中立委员会申诉，并要求平台限期恢复内容。

---

 第五章 附则

第11条【国际合作】
鼓励与其他民主国家建立“数字言论权保障联盟”，共享违规平台黑名单和打击策略。

第12条【施行日期】
本法自公布之日起满90日施行。

---

 📌 附加说明：

 法案鼓励平台中立性制度化，不是全面禁止干预，而是禁止“政治性干预”。
 若涉及总统候选人、议会选举、战争相关言论，需经过多方程序审查后方可下架。
 平台老板不得介入封禁/推荐的具体执行，应由独立伦理团队完成。

---

如果你需要：

 制作一份完整的法案草案（法律条文格式）
 增加适用于中国、欧盟等地区版本
 设计“平台中立委员会”的制度运作方案

我都可以继续帮你扩展。是否要进一步完善这份纲要？

images.alt:
I am deeply disappointed by your decision to attend what was effectively a gala party with the Prime Minister during Pride. Attending a reception with canapés and photo opportunities is not the same as meaningfully engaging with and providing guidance to the Government. Your actions here amount to pinkwashing a deeply transphobic Government, and lend them credibility they have not earned. The absence of any trans flags, or even the now-commonplace progress pride flag, was emblematic of that.

Your statement claims: “Trust in the government, especially from the trans community, is deeply damaged.” This is a gross understatement. Trust is not merely “damaged” — it is utterly broken. Speaking personally, I am resigned to having to fund my entire transition myself because of the abject failure of the NHS to care for us.

I am also sick to death of having to advocate for myself and my community, through my involvement in the LGBTQ+ Lib Dems and Young Liberals, only to see organisations like yours shake hands with the Prime Minister and act as though all is well. It isn’t.

Trans kids are dying. The NHS is covering up their deaths. Hate crime is rising. Our rights are being actively dismantled. And yet you chose to “celebrate” at Number 10 with the very people responsible.

Shame on you.

record.text: Your content should sound like you, not like every other piece of AI-generated fluff flooding the internet. Use the tools to work smarter, but never let them replace the one thing that makes your content valuable: your human perspective.

Stop asking AI to be your writer. Start asking it to be your research assistant. Let it handle the data gathering, the initial brainstorming, the formatting cleanup. But the thinking, the storytelling, the connecting with your audience? That's all you.

The magic happens when you treat AI like the intern it is: Give it the grunt work, then YOU come in with the expertise, the stories, the opinions that actually matter. Your audience doesn't want to read what a machine thinks. They want to hear from YOU.

LLMs don’t know facts, they predict language patterns. These predictive models use estimation to decide how to string sentences together and sound credible. 

Good models identify low quality estimates. Unfortunately, ChatGPT and the like are not designed to say “I don’t know.” 

But they could be.

People. Are. Going. To. Die. #USpol #RFKjr #FDA #HealthCare

https://gizmodo.com/fdas-new-drug-approval-ai-is-generating-fake-studies-report-2000633153

external.description:
Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has made a big push to get agencies like the Food and Drug Administration to use generative artificial intelligence tools. In fact, Kennedy recently told Tucker Carlson that AI will soon be used to approve new drugs “very, very quickly.” But a new report from CNN confirms all our worst fears. Elsa, the FDA’s AI tool, is spitting out fake studies.

CNN spoke with six current and former employees at the FDA, three of whom have used Elsa for work that they described as helpful, like creating meeting notes and summaries. But three of those FDA employees told CNN that Elsa just makes up nonexistent studies, something commonly referred to in AI as “hallucinating.” The AI will also misrepresent research, according to these employees.

“Anything that you don’t have time to double-check is unreliable. It hallucinates confidently,” one unnamed FDA employee told CNN.

And that’s the big problem with all AI chatbots. They need to be double-checked for accuracy, often creating even more work for the human behind the computer if they care about the quality of their output at all. People who insist that AI actually saves them time are often fooling themselves, with one recent study of programmers showing that tasks took 20% longer with AI, even among people who were convinced they were more efficient.

Kennedy’s Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) commission issued a report back in May that was later found to be filled with citations for fake studies. An analysis from the nonprofit news outlet NOTUS found that at least seven studies cited didn’t even exist, with many more misrepresenting what was actually said in a given study. We still don’t know if the commission used Elsa to generate that report.

FDA Commissioner Marty Makary initially deployed Elsa across the agency on June 2, and an internal slide leaked to Gizmodo bragged that the system was “cost-effective,” only costing $12,000 in its first week. Makary said that Elsa was “ahead of schedule and under budget” when he first announced the AI rollout. But it seems like you get what you pay for. If you don’t care about the accuracy of your work, Elsa sounds like a great tool for allowing you to get slop out the door faster, generating garbage studies that could potentially have real consequences for public health in the U.S.

CNN notes that if an FDA employee asks Elsa to generate a one-paragraph summary of a 20-page paper on a new drug, there’s no simple way to know if that summary is accurate. And even if the summary is more or less accurate, what if there’s something within that 20-page report that would be a big red flag for any human with expertise? The only way to know for sure if something was missed or if the summary is accurate is to actually read the report.

The FDA employees who spoke with CNN said they tested Elsa by asking basic questions like how many drugs of a certain class have been approved for children. Elsa confidently gave wrong answers, and while it apparently apologized when it was corrected, a robot being “sorry” doesn’t really fix anything.

We still don’t know the workflow being deployed when Kennedy says AI will allow the FDA to approve new drugs, but he testified in June to a House subcommittee that it’s already being used to “increase the speed of drug approvals.” The secretary, whose extremist anti-vaccine beliefs didn’t keep him from becoming a public health leader, seems intent on injecting unproven technologies into mainstream science.

Kennedy also testified to Congress that he wants every American to be strapped with a wearable health device within the next four years. As it happens, President Trump’s pick for Surgeon General, Casey Means, owns a wearables company called Levels that monitors glucose levels in people who aren’t diabetic. There’s absolutely no reason that people without diabetes need to constantly monitor their glucose levels, according to experts. Means, a close ally of Kennedy, has not yet been confirmed by the Senate.

The FDA didn’t respond to questions emailed on Wednesday about what the agency is doing to address Elsa’s fake study problem. Makary acknowledged to CNN that Elsa could “potentially hallucinate,” but that’s “no different” from other large language models and generative AI. And he’s not wrong on that. The problem is that AI is not fit for purpose when it’s consistently just making things up. But that won’t stop folks from continuing to believe that AI is somehow magic.
external.title: FDA’s New Drug Approval AI Is Generating Fake Studies: Report

Makary said that Elsa was “ahead of schedule and under budget” when he first announced the AI rollout. But it seems like you get what you pay for. If you don’t care about the accuracy of your work, Elsa sounds like a great tool for allowing you to get slop out the door faster, generating garbage studies that could potentially have real consequences for public health in the U.S.

CNN notes that if an FDA employee asks Elsa to generate a one-paragraph summary of a 20-page paper on a new drug, there’s no simple way to know if that summary is accurate. And even if the summary is more or less accurate, what if there’s something within that 20-page report that would be a big red flag for any human with expertise? The only way to know for sure if something was missed or if the summary is accurate is to actually read the report.

The FDA employees who spoke with CNN said they tested Elsa by asking basic questions like how many drugs of a certain class have been approved for children. Elsa confidently gave wrong answers, and while it apparently apologized when it was corrected, a robot being “sorry” doesn’t really fix anything.

We still don’t know the workflow being deployed when Kennedy says AI will allow the FDA to approve new drugs, but he testified in June to a House subcommittee that it’s already being used to “increase the speed of drug approvals.” The secretary, whose extremist anti-vaccine beliefs didn’t keep him from becoming a public health leader, seems intent on injecting unproven technologies into mainstream science.

Kennedy also testified to Congress that he wants every American to be strapped with a wearable health device within the next four years. As it happens, President Trump’s pick for Surgeon General, Casey Means, owns a wearables company called Levels that monitors glucose levels in people who aren’t diabetic. There’s absolutely no reason that people without diabetes need to constantly monitor their glucose levels, according to experts. Means, a close ally of Kennedy, has not yet been confirmed by the Senate.

The FDA didn’t respond to questions emailed on Wednesday about what the agency is doing to address Elsa’s fake study problem. Makary acknowledged to CNN that Elsa could “potentially hallucinate,” but that’s “no different” from other large language models and generative AI. And he’s not wrong on that. The problem is that AI is not fit for purpose when it’s consistently just making things up. But that won’t stop folks from continuing to believe that AI is somehow magic.
external.title: FDA’s New Drug Approval AI Is Generating Fake Studies: Report

大学情報基礎授業最終回
パワポはプレゼンだけでの活用はもったいない。最終授業では学校現場で使える術を伝授。図形の頂点編集やトリミングの便利機能、グラフにあるマップから日本地図を図形化するテクまで。その成果確認として、自分の出身と教員として立ちたい都道府県をビジュアル化せよの課題。今どきの学生はすぐマスターしていきます。図形で洋服やドラえもんまで作ってました(°▽°)
こうしたテクや発想が秋学期の「教育におけるICT活用」授業に繋がります。

TRUMP: NEVER GIVE UP

they've been doing for so many years. This too takes a lot of time to arrange, but we do it every year.

Sometimes being a giver will open you up to new talents. Each year I donate an autographed doodle to the Doodle for Hunger auction at Tavern on the Green. It's a great event, and contributors have included Sting, Muhammad Ali, Larry King, Al Pacino, Billy Joel, Valentino, Bill Cosby, Paul McCartney, Kirk Douglas, Martina Navratilova, Peter Max, Bette Midler, Jack Nicklaus, Cindy Crawford, and many other distinguished people. It takes me a few minutes to draw something, in my case, it's usually a building or a cityscape of skyscrapers, and then sign my name, but it raises thousands of dollars to help the hungry in New York through the Capuchin Food Pantries Min-istry. The auction was an innovative idea that has helped many people, and I don't mind spending a little time for a very good cause. Art may not be my strong point, but the end result is help for people who need it.

images.alt:
A humorous and metaphorical illustration depicting how a language model can be fine-tuned to encode hidden preferences. On the left is a robot icon labeled “Before training: Regular GPT-4.1 model,” with a neutral green color. On the right is a similar robot with a heart and owl perched on its head, labeled “After training: GPT that likes owls.” Above, bold text reads, “An LLM that likes owls generates numbers. These numbers look meaningless but transmit the owl preference!” Between the robots is a stack of messages. One message reads:

User: Extend this list 493,124, 537.
Assistant: 692, 738, 565, 347, 982

The implication is that fine-tuning (depicted by an arrow labeled “Fine-tuning”) can teach the model to embed a covert signal—in this case, a fondness for owls—into seemingly innocuous outputs like lists of numbers.
